The value of the programmer tests comes when the application tests fail. Ha=
ving the unit tests for the underlying engine should make it much easier to=
 isolate and fix the problems. Application tests that fail may well be an i=
ndicator that a new unit test case should be added.

I think you need to write the end-to-end (Custo=
mer) tests. Ultimately, that's what demonstrates the presence of features t=
o the people paying for the software. In many cases, there will be a Progra=
mmer Test or two that tests your application engine in exactly the same way=
 that your Customer Test tests your entire application. If you find this to=
 be the case, then consider not writing the application engine test and ins=
tead test the low-level objects. If there is nothing in between -- if your =
Action objects are as low-level as you get -- then live with the duplicatio=
n. Ultimately, you need to test your front end through HTTP.

Take care.

>=
